Fig. 2 FTIR results. Fig. 3 XPS spectra. Fig. 4 Thermogravimetric analysis (sample carbonized at 550°C). Fig. 5 Sulfonic groups content dependence on the carbonization temperature. Fig. 6 Conversion dependence on the sulfonic groups content and relation between sulfonic groups content and the turnover number (t =110°C, 100g/L, weight ratio catalyst/cellobiose 0.5, t =24h). Fig. 7 R dependence on the sulphur concentration. Fig. 8 TON dependence on R. Table 1 Carbonized burn-off and oxygen concentration. Carbonization temperature (°C) Oxygen concentration (%m/m) %Burn-off 250 39.4 17.9 300 30.2 46.8 350 27.6 52.3 450 19.4 64.9 550 6.3 72.8 Table 2 Elemental quantitative analysis. Carbonization temperature (°C) Oxygenated groups b (mmol/g) 100 S/C (elemental analysis) 100 S/C (XPS) R a 250 5.7 0.68 6.4 9.47 300 4.3 2.84 2.80 0.99 350 4.4 2.73 2.54 0.93 450 3.3 2.22 2.86 1.29 550 5.4 0.80 3.13 3.92 a R is the ratio S/C (XPS)/S/C (elemental analysis). b Carboxylic acids. Table 3 Typical values of sulfonic groups concentration and optimum carbonization temperature in the literature. Rovisco Pais Lisboa 1049-001 Portugal ⁎ Corresponding author at: Av. Horácio Macedo, 950, Cidade Universitária, Rio de Janeiro, RJ CEP 21.941-915, Brazil. Fax: +55 21-21625036. Graphical abstract The conversion of cellulose into products with higher added value often includes a depolymerization step to obtain glucose, its fundamental unity. The depolymerization reaction is carried out via hydrolysis of the β-1,4-glycosidic bond. The search for a solid acid catalyst capable of breaking these bonds is gaining increasing prominence in the literature. In this regard, sulfonated carbons have shown promising results. This work evaluated the use of a residue from the extraction of palm oil as raw material for the production of sulfonated carbons. The raw material was carbonized and sulfonated. The obtained solid acids were tested in the hydrolysis of cellobiose, a dimer of glucose often used as a model compound for cellulose. The hydrolysis reaction is the first step in converting renewable carbon sources into chemical products and biofuels. Some aspects were investigated, as the effect of carbonization temperature on the concentration of sulfonic groups, the results showing that the content thereof reached a maximum value at 300°C. Regarding the hydrolysis of cellobiose, it has been identified that there is a relationship between the concentration of sulfonic acid groups and the activity of these catalysts. However, there is a drop in the turnover number as the amount of sulfonic acid sites increases. This was related to a preferred position sulfonation mechanism. Furthermore, sulfonated carbons showed higher activity than the commercial acid resins, indicating that this material may be a good option for the generation of solid acid catalysts. Keywords Oligomers Hydrolysis Biomass Solid acids 1 Introduction The conversion of cellulose into products with higher added value often includes a depolymerization step to obtain glucose, via the hydrolysis of the β-1,4-glycosidic bond. However, to enable hydrolysis of β-1,4 glycosidic bonds, strong Bronsted acids are required. Many solids display strong Bronsted acid sites. The achievement of hydrolysis reaction with a solid acid is still a challenge. Traditionally, the reaction is carried out using inorganic acids as catalysts. Nevertheless, some aspects such as corrosion of process units, make the use of solid acids rather attractive. The literature reports interesting results using sulfonated carbons, which may be easily recycled and have sulfonic acid groups with acid strength similar to sulfuric acid [1]. Along with applications in esterification and transesterification for biodiesel production [2,3], cellulose and oligosaccharide hydrolysis reactions are the most common applications of sulfonated carbons presented in the literature. Cellulose is a linear polymer molecule formed by glucopyranose rings linked by β-1,4 chemical bonds, between carbons 1 and 4 of the ring. This type of connection provides a higher stability to cellulose compared to other polysaccharides such as starch, which is formed by α-1,4 chemical bonds. Due to the symmetry of the β-1,4 bond, hydrogen bonds between adjacent hydroxyl groups of the two rings are formed, increasing stability of the β-1,4 bond. β-1,4 chemical bonds decrease the water solubility of oligosaccharides even with few rings, thereby protecting the β-1,4 glycosidic bond from hydrolysis reactions [4]. Oligosaccharides are molecules consisting of 2–10 monosaccharides such as glucose, whereas polysaccharides are formed by a larger amount of monosaccharides. Amylose, for instance, is a polysaccharide whose degree of polymerization ranges from 250 to 3000, a rather low value when compared to the values observed for cellulose, which may reach 10,000. Examples of oligosaccharides that have β-1,4 glycosidic bonds are cellobiose, with two rings of glucose, cellotriose (3 rings), celotetraose (4 rings), and so forth. These polymers are cellulose fragments, having in their structure the same chemical bond; thus, one expects them to behave like cellulose in the reaction of hydrolysis to yield sugars. For that reason, such oligosaccharides are often used as a probe molecule in reactions of hydrolysis. Another interesting approach recently reported in the literature is the use of monophasic co-solvent systems, in special, gamma-valerolactone, which is capable of solubilize cellulose decomposition products, and could be coupled with cellulose catalytic deconstruction, improving catalyst life by solubilizing humins that could be formed during hydrolysis reactions [5,6]. It is well known that the introduction of sulfonic acid groups (-SO3H) on the surface of a carbon changes the pH of the surface thereof, changing the adsorption characteristics and making these carbons suitable for the application in heterogeneous acid catalysis. Although the main application of these sulfonated carbons is as acid catalysts [7], the application of these materials in adsorption of ammonia [8] and as a support for metal catalysts [9–12] has also shown promising results. Accordingly, the introduction of sulfonic acid groups in these materials gained importance because it allowed the generation of a new class of solid acid catalyst with good properties, especially for reactions of hydrolysis and esterification [13]. The introduction of sulfonic acid groups is reached by the reaction between the sulfonating agent and the aromatic rings that make up the structure of the carbon, through an electrophilic substitution mechanism [14,15]. Under sulfonation conditions, both the sulfonating agent and the carbon surface characteristics, are important parameters that will influence the amount of sulfonic groups introduced in the carbonaceous matrix. The acidic characteristic of sulfonated carbons is due to the ionization of the sulfonic acid group acting as a strong acid, as can be seen in Eq. (1). The same mechanism is used for sulfonated polymer ion exchange resin where the hydrogen of the sulfonic group is replaced by a cation in solution [8,16]. Other existing functional groups on carbon (Cn) surface, such as phenolic hydroxyls and carboxylic acids, may also cause acidity. However, the acid strength of the sulfonic acid groups is responsible for most of the surface acidity of these carbons. (1) Cn-SO3H+H2O→Cn-SO3 − +H3O+ Typically, the first step of the sulfonated carbons preparation is the creation of the carbonaceous matrix which is the basis for anchoring sulfonic acid groups. This step can be performed starting from 3 different groups of materials, these being the carbonaceous material as received, the carbonized material at intermediate temperatures or after obtaining activated carbons at higher temperatures [17,18]. The sulfonation may be performed using any compound containing sulfur, being the sulfuric acid the most common agent [19]. The stability of sulfonic acid groups is the main goal of most studies, allowing the reuse of the solids [2,14,20]. In fact, many authors claim that sulfonated carbons undergo slight deactivation reaching a plateau of stability after being reused several times [17–22]. In this sense, the main variables assessed in the literature are the kind of raw materials available for the sulfonation, the sulfonating agent and its concentration, the temperature of sulfonation, the mass ratio between the sulfonating agent and the raw material and the atmosphere in which the sulfonation is carried out [3]. The best results that have been reported indicate that the sulfonation of not completely carbonized materials would generate larger amount of acid sites thermally stable. The most common sulfonating agent in research papers is sulfuric acid in its most concentrated form. Temperatures of sulfonation vary considerably and tend to be in the range of 100–150°C. Normally, the weight ratio between the sulfonating agent and the raw material is more than 10, while the atmosphere may be an inert gas or air. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Catalyst preparation The sulfonated carbons were obtained from palm kernel shells, an abundant residue of the palm oil industry. For the carbonization step the palm kernel shell was loaded into a quartz reactor and placed in a bipartite oven. A flow of nitrogen of 3.75 NmLmin−1 gshell −1 was regulated with upward flow. A ramp of 10°Cmin−1 from ambient temperature was programmed to the desired carbonization temperature and a step of 4h was carried out after reaching this temperature. At the end of the process, the oven was immediately opened to a rapid sample cooling. For all the samples the burn-off value, which is the mass of matter lost due to gasification reactions in carbonization, was calculated. Its value can be obtained by Eq. (2). (2) % Burn − off = m shellin − m carbout m shellin × 100 where m shellin is the mass of palm kernel shell loaded into the reactor, and m carbout is the mass of carbonized material obtained at the end of the carbonization process. Sulfonation was conducted at 120°C for 6h with concentrated sulfuric acid. The mass ratio of sulfuric acid to carbonized material used was 10. The slurry formed by the acid–carbonized mixture was kept under stirring and under nitrogen atmosphere during the sulfonation time. After sulfonation, the solid was filtered and washed with distilled water until the wash water presents neutral pH. Additionally, the washing water was tested with barium chloride solution to detect sulfate ions. Cellobiose adsorption at room temperature was measured adding 0.5g of each sulfonated carbon to 10mL of a 0.29mol/L cellobiose solution. The system was stirred for 4h and then cellobiose concentration measured via HPLC. Only cellobiose was detected in liquid phase indicating that hydrolysis reactions does not occurs at this temperature. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were collected with Rigaku Miniflex II, using a monochromator with Cu-Kα radiation (30kV and 15mA) over a 2θ range of 2–90°, with step of 0.05° and 2s by step. Surface functional groups were analyzed using FTIR. FTIR spectra were obtained using a FTIR spectrometer, ThermoFisher Avatar 360 with 32 scans at a resolution of 4cm−1, between 400 and 4000cm−1. Thermogravimetric analysis was conducted, using the ASTM E1131 method, using a temperature programming until 1000°C at a heating rate of 20°C/min and nitrogen flow of 50mL/min. The samples were characterized by elemental analysis to determine sulfur, carbon, oxygen and nitrogen concentrations. The analysis was carried out on CHNS equipment ThermoFinnigan FLASH EA 1110 Fisons EA1112. Surface composition was assessed by XPS Spectra were recorded using non-monochromatic Al Kα radiation (hν =1486.6eV) from an XSAM800 (KRATOS) XPS dual anode spectrometer. Spectra acquisition conditions and data treatment details were reported elsewhere [23]. For quantitative purposes, the following sensitivity factors were used: C 1s: 0.25; O 1s: 0.66; N 1s: 0.42; S 2p: 0.54. The total concentration of sulfonic groups has been determined using chemical analysis via the technique CHNS. The concentration of sulfonic groups on the outer surface of the particle has been determined using XPS. The parameter R represents the ratio between sulphur detected via both techniques. It was assumed that all sulphur present in the samples comes from sulfonic groups. 2.3 Catalytic evaluation procedure In hydrolysis tests, cellobiose from Sigma–Aldrich (purity>98.0%) and distilled water were used. As a reference catalyst, the sulfonic resin Amberlyst 36 was used. Hydrolysis tests were conducted under agitation using the following conditions, based on preliminary results: 110°C, cellobiose concentration of 100g/L, weight ratio catalyst/cellobiose was 0.5, and a reaction time of 24h, using a batch reactor, attached with condenser, immersed in a silicone bath with temperature control. At the end of test, the product was filtered and an aliquot was taken for chromatographic analysis. The equipment used for the chromatographic analysis was an Agilent HPLC Technologies 1100 series with thermostated sampler series 1260 with a RID detector (refractive index). The chromatographic column used in the analyses was AMINEX HPX 87-H. The method used the following conditions: mobile phase: 5mM H2SO4, flow rate: 0.7mL/min, column temperature: 65°C and running time: 65min. Diffusion limitations (both external and internal) must be determined, being more relevant when the reaction is carried out either with catalysts presenting large particles sizes or with reactions performed without agitation. Since our particles were rather small (50μm) and very intense agitation (1000rpm) has been used, intraparticle and interparticle diffusion limitations have been disregarded. As there were no solvent losses, the conversion of cellobiose was calculated based on the solution concentrations according to Eq. (3). (3) X CB = C CBi − C CBf C CBi × 100 where C CBi and C CBf are the initial and final cellobiose concentrations in solution. 3 Results and discussion The first step to prepare the sulfonated carbons was the carbonization of palm kernel shells. As expected, the increase of carbonization temperature led to an increase in the burn-off percentage observed for the samples, as depicted in Table 1 . As a consequence, there was a gradual reduction in the oxygen content present in the carbonized material. Several studies have shown that the carbonization temperature has a huge effect on the subsequent stage of sulfonation of the material. It is generally accepted that the carbonization temperature is related to the organization and size of the sheets of aromatic carbon that compose the carbonized material. Higher carbonization temperatures generate larger and better organized aromatic sheets, leaving less accessible sites for the sulfonation on the internal part of the material [24,25]. This is the main reason why activated carbons, always prepared at very high carbonization temperatures, must not be used as carbon matrix for sulfonation. The increase in aromatic sheets size and organization increases the crystallinity of the material. As can be seen in Fig. 1 , all the samples showed a characteristic diffraction pattern with one broad band located at 2θ range of 20–30° related to the presence of non-graphitic carbon. Samples prepared at higher carbonization temperature exhibited a more intense signal at this band indicating an increase in the carbon ordering. In the range of 40–50° it is possible to observe one band related to graphitic carbon. Only the sample carbonized at the highest temperature showed this band. FTIR spectroscopy was used to assess the presence of surface functional groups. As an example of the data obtained, Fig. 2 shows the results for one sulfonated carbon and its pre-carbonized precursor. All sulfonated carbons exhibited similar results. After sulfonation the appearance of bands at 1035 and 1200cm−1 was observed, and attributed to sulfonic groups, confirming that the sulfonation reaction proceeded successfully [26–28]. The band located at 3413cm−1 was associated with -OH in carboxylic acids or in phenols [29,30]. This is an indication that the sulfonation not only creates sulfonic groups but inserts other functional groups on the carbon surface due to oxidizing reactions. The other most strong band observed at 1615cm−1 was assigned to the CC bond in polyaromatic compounds, characteristic of carbonized materials. BET analysis of the prepared carbons revealed very low surface areas (1–2m2/g). These results are in accordance with what has been observed in literature [1,17,21]. Such low surfaces would apparently contradict the results of high catalytic activity. Nevertheless, as pointed out previously such carbons have the capacity of incorporating molecules of hydrophilic solvents, which is the case of water. Indeed, adsorption of water indicated much higher surfaces (260–560m2/g—[17,21]). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was used to shed light on the surface composition. All sulfonated carbons showed, on the S 2p spectrum (Fig. 3 ), a single doublet with the main component, S2p3/2 centered at 168.7±0.1eV for two of the samples (at the two extreme temperatures), assigned to the presence of sulfonic groups. For all the other samples, two doublets are identified: one with the S 2p3/2 component centered at 167.7±0.2eV, again assigned to sulfonic groups and another one with the S 2p3/2 component centered at 163.7±0.1eV corresponding to a reduced form of sulphur. The C 1s spectrum showed peaks at 284.4eV related to CC bond confirming the presence of graphitic carbon, at 285.0eV related to CC bond and 286eV assigned to CO which is one more indication of the presence of surface oxygenated groups. Nitrogen spectrum N 1s showed bands at 399.9eV for all the sulfonated carbons prepared above 250°C, which were related to the presence of non-protonated amines. All sulfonated carbons exhibited one band at 401.5eV, which was assigned to protonated primary amines. Only the catalyst prepared at 250°C showed one band at 402.5eV, indicating the presence of protonated tertiary amines. Quantitatively, the relative amounts of sulphur (expressed as the atomic ratio S/C) at the surface (Table 2 ) follow a pattern which contradicts the one obtained by elemental analysis. Elemental analysis shows that the functionalization with sulphur of both the surface and the bulk are completely different. Also, some nitrogen was detected with relative amounts following the same patterns as the ones for sulphur. In Fig. 4 the thermogravimetric analysis of sulfonated carbon prepared using material carbonized at 550°C is shown. One well defined decomposition peak at 250°C can be observed. Such peak was assigned to the thermal decomposition of sulfonic groups [31]. The mass loss related to the decomposition peak at 250°C is in excellent agreement with the amount of sulfonic groups concentration obtained by elemental analysis. For the other samples the mass loss at this temperature range is related not only to the sulfonic groups but also to the carbon matrix decomposition, hence it is impossible to correlate the sulfonic groups concentration with TGA results in these cases. In Fig. 5 it is possible to observe the concentration of sulfonic groups present in the carbon as a function of carbonization temperature. It can be noticed that the higher content of sulfonic acid groups was obtained for the samples that were generated from carbonized materials at 300°C and 350°C. The same behavior has been mentioned in the literature, which states that, at low carbonization temperature, many degradation products remain in the carbonaceous structure, thereby not allowing a complete sulfonation of the material. At elevated temperatures, the increase in size and organization of the aromatic sheets brings about less sites accessible for the anchoring of sulfonic acid groups. A higher carbonization temperature also makes the carbonaceous structure more rigid, which makes the entry of reagents more difficult [25,32–34]. Thus, there is a point of maximum efficiency for the sulfonation of palm kernel shells, and this value seems to be in the range of 300–350°C. The values obtained for the concentration of sulfonic acid groups are in agreement with the range reported in the literature for various materials and conditions of sulfonation, as can be seen in Table 3 [1,24,25,32,33,35–37]. Higher concentrations of sulfonic acid groups seem to be possible by using more drastic sulfonation conditions, as higher temperatures, longer times and the use of fuming sulfuric acid. Regarding the carbonization temperature, as can be seen in Table 3, most studies report values of 400°C as optimum temperature for carbonizing materials such as glucose, sucrose and cellulose. Few studies are available with lignocellulosic residues. In this sense, a study was published in which the optimal carbonization temperature obtained for sugarcane bagasse was 375°C [32], closer to that obtained in this work for palm kernel shell. According to the results obtained and comparison with the literature it is possible to conclude that the optimum carbonization temperature depends on the type of raw material used. Nonetheless, the optimum range is relatively narrow, ranging from 300 to 400°C. As shown in the results of XPS, DRX, FTIR, TGA and elemental analysis, the carbonization and sulfonation procedures were capable of creating a carbon matrix with attached sulfonic acid sites, in agreement with the patterns reported in the literature for this kind of material. The sulfonated carbons prepared were tested in the reaction of cellobiose hydrolysis. All tests were performed in duplicates and the reported results are the averages. The blank test at reaction conditions give conversions lower than 2%, already discounted of values presented for other tests. The yield in glucose in cellobiose hydrolysis was nearly 100% in all cases. Traces of HMF (below 10ppm), a product of glucose degradation, have been detected in some cases. It is observed in Fig. 6 that there seems to be a dependency between the content of sulfonic acid groups in the sulfonated carbons and the conversion level achieved. The content of sulfonic acid groups seems to be the most important variable in the cellobiose hydrolysis. However, when compared with other materials one can see that the content of sulfonic acid groups alone does not explain the success of the application of sulfonated carbons in this reaction. As a reference, sulfonic resin Amberlyst 36 having 5.4mmol/g of sulfonic acid groups was used. This resin had an average conversion of 79%. Despite having more than 5 times the amount of sulfonic acid groups than the sulfonated carbons produced, its conversion was a few percentage points lower. Although a classic kinetic evaluation has not been carried out, since activities have been determined at very long reaction time, one must bear in mind that conversions at 24h reaction time are a clear indication that sulfonated carbons are better catalysts than Amberlyst for the hydrolysis of cellobiose, as previously observed in many references [1,21,37]. Indeed, similar results have been widely observed in the literature and the most well accepted explanation for this phenomenon is the existence of other oxygenated groups in sulfonated carbons that interact with cellobiose molecule via hydrogen bonds. This interaction leads to the loss of hydrogen bonds within and between molecules observed in molecular cellobiose. Such hydrogen bonds protect the β-1,4-glycosidic bond, therefore their disappearance makes the glycosidic bond more readily hydrolysable [1,37]. This reaction mechanism was correlated with that observed when cellulase enzymes are used. In this case there are two active sites, the first being called the binding domain which would be equivalent to oxygenated groups on the sulfonated carbons. The second is the catalytic domain that effectively promotes the hydrolysis reactions and would be equivalent to sulfonic acid group [39]. Cellobiose adsorption tests were performed at 25°C and it was observed that 3–4% of cellobiose was adsorbed by the sulfonated carbons at this condition. No adsorption was observed for Amberlyst 36 resin. These results are in agreement with those observed in the literature, that reported 2–4% cellobiose adsorbed onto sulfonated carbons and correlated this fact to its high hydrolysis reaction rate compared to other solid acids [26,37]. However, the analysis of the conversion data using the turnover number (TON) showed other important aspects of this catalytic system. The turnover number corresponds to the number of molecules of cellobiose converted per catalytic active site. Interestingly, it can be seen in Fig. 6 that with the increasing number of active sites the turnover number drops. Clearly, this is an indication that there are other factors causing differences in activity in sulfonic acid groups. It has been proposed that this behavior is related to a preferred position sulfonation mechanism. When there are few sulfonation sites, as in materials carbonized at temperatures far from optimum conditions, the introduction of sulfonic groups occurs primarily in more accessible positions making these sites more active for the hydrolysis reactions. On the other hand, carbons with huge amounts of sulfonation positions have sites located not only at easily accessible positions but also internal ones, that are more difficult to be reached by reactants and could present diffusion limitations. To confirm this hypothesis one new variable has been defined to help us enlighten such phenomenon. The new variable, named R, is the ratio between the concentration of sulphur at surface and the concentration of bulk sulphur and its values are presented in Table 2. This variable measures how the distribution of sulphur species between bulk and surface occurs. As one can observe in Fig. 7 , as the concentration of sulphur decreases as a higher value of R is obtained, indicating that a higher fraction of sulphur atoms are at the catalyst surface as sulfonic acid sites. This is an indication that the sulfonation proceeds via a preferred position mechanism, starting from the surface and going to deeper carbon layers. This special distribution of the acidic sulfonic sites creates differences in the accessibility, which ultimately affects the catalyst performance. This explains why the turnover number increases with R, as can be seen in Fig. 8 . Higher R values mean that a higher fraction of sulphur is at the surface, being thus more accessible. Such sites are able to convert more easily cellobiose units, causing an increase in the turnover number. From these results it is possible to conclude that the extent of sulfonation process influences directly the apparent activity of the sulfonic acid sites. An increase in the number of active sites is not proportional to the increase in catalytic activity, since the additional sulfonic sites may be less accessible. This phenomenon ultimately causes a reduction in the average number of molecules of cellobiose converted per site. 4 Conclusions The use of palm kernel shell, a low value residue of the palm oil industry, as raw material to obtain a highly active solid acid for cellobiose hydrolysis reactions was demonstrated. It was observed that the conversion of cellobiose is proportional to the amount of sulfonic acid groups in the sulfonated carbon, and this content is dependent on the carbonization temperature to which the material was subjected. The optimum temperature of carbonization is in the range of 300–350°C. The activity of the best carbons was superior to the activity of synthetic resins with higher sulfonic groups’ content. This behavior was related to the presence of other oxygenated groups at the surface of the carbons, which act as binding domains and make easier the occurrence of hydrolysis reactions. Moreover, a drop in the turnover number was observed with the increase in the amount of sulfonic groups. To explain this phenomenon the mechanism of preferred sulfonation position at the surface was proposed and confirmed by quantitative XPS. It states that lower amounts of sulfonic groups are located at positions with better access to reactants. Nevertheless, as the amount of sulfonic groups increases, new sulfonic groups begin to be located at positions that could be subjected to diffusion limitations. References [1] M. coredata.dc:description: The conversion of cellulose into products with higher added value often includes a depolymerization step to obtain glucose, its fundamental unity. The depolymerization reaction is carried out via hydrolysis of the β-1,4-glycosidic bond. The search for a solid acid catalyst capable of breaking these bonds is gaining increasing prominence in the literature. In this regard, sulfonated carbons have shown promising results. This work evaluated the use of a residue from the extraction of palm oil as raw material for the production of sulfonated carbons. The raw material was carbonized and sulfonated. The obtained solid acids were tested in the hydrolysis of cellobiose, a dimer of glucose often used as a model compound for cellulose. The hydrolysis reaction is the first step in converting renewable carbon sources into chemical products and biofuels. Some aspects were investigated, as the effect of carbonization temperature on the concentration of sulfonic groups, the results showing that the content thereof reached a maximum value at 300°C. Regarding the hydrolysis of cellobiose, it has been identified that there is a relationship between the concentration of sulfonic acid groups and the activity of these catalysts. However, there is a drop in the turnover number as the amount of sulfonic acid sites increases. This was related to a preferred position sulfonation mechanism. Furthermore, sulfonated carbons showed higher activity than the commercial acid resins, indicating that this material may be a good option for the generation of solid acid catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Biomass derived solid acids as effective hydrolysis catalysts
coredata.prism:issueName: Contributions of Homogeneous and Heterogeneous Catalysis in Biorefining: Special Issue in Honor of Prof. Ulf Schuchardt
